event.description: The Liverpool and Manchester Railway opens, marking the debut of George Stephenson's groundbreaking locomotive, "The Rocket," setting new standards for speed and efficiency in railway travel.
The Grand Junction Railway, the world's first long-distance railway, is opened in England, connecting Birmingham to Warrington.
The first railway to span a nation, the Great Indian Peninsula Railway, begins operations in India, significantly enhancing transportation across the subcontinent.
The completion of the First Transcontinental Railroad in the United States, linking the east and west coasts and revolutionizing travel and commerce across the country.
The American Railway Association introduces standard time zones, allowing for consistent schedules and timetables across the expanding railway network.
The inauguration of the Forth Railway Bridge in Scotland, a pioneering steel structure and a symbol of engineering excellence in railway infrastructure.
The formation of the "Big Four" railway companies in the United Kingdom following the grouping of various smaller companies, leading to more efficient management and operations.
The introduction of the streamlined "Flying Scotsman" train service in the United Kingdom, exemplifying speed and modern design in railway travel.
The introduction of Japan's high-speed "Shinkansen" bullet train, setting new standards for speed, safety, and comfort in rail transportation.
The opening of France's TGV (Train Ã Grande Vitesse), Europe's first high-speed rail service, revolutionizing travel on the continent.
China debuts its high-speed rail system, showcasing technological advancements and rapidly expanding the world's largest network of high-speed trains.

Continued advancements in railway technology include the development of maglev trains and further expansion of high-speed rail networks worldwide, emphasizing sustainability and efficiency in modern transportation systems.

fact.title: Longest Railway
fact.description: The Trans-Siberian Railway is the world's longest railway, spanning approximately 9,289 kilometers.

fact.title: High-Speed Train
fact.description: The Shinkansen in Japan is one of the fastest trains in the world, reaching speeds of up to 320 km/h.

model.name: ICE 4
model.description: The Intercity-Express 4 is a high-speed train operated in Germany and other European countries.

model.name: Maglev
model.description: Magnetic levitation trains use magnetic fields for propulsion, achieving high speeds with minimal friction.
